description: Dive into "Seville's Picture-Perfect Moments Await" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Seville's Picture-Perfect Moments Await

places.generalDescription: The Royal Alc√°zar of Seville is a landmark Moorish royal palace featuring fountain-filled gardens, ornate arches, and 16th-century tiles. It is considered one of the finest examples of Mudejar architecture in Spain, showcasing a blend of Moorish and Renaissance styles. The palace complex has a rich history dating back to the 10th century when it was initially built as a Moorish fortress.

sources.snippet: Royal Alc√°zar of Seville has to be the crown jewel of Seville. And quite literally, because it was built as a house for kings and still is the house of kings ‚Äì the upper floors of Alc√°zar still host the royal family when they visit the city of Seville. Royal Alc√°zar of Seville is a complex that consists of palaces, patios, courtyards, staterooms, unique bathing rooms, and massive gardens with pathways, ponds, fountains, trees and flowers, benches, pavilions, and even a maze.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: The Alcazar of Seville (official name Alc√°zares Reales de Sevilla) ‚Äì is the crowning glory of Seville and its most impressive monument. It‚Äôs still actively used as the residence of Royal family and one of the most visited monuments in Andalusia. The Royal Alcazar features some of the finest examples of Mudejar style, and combines elements of Roman, Gothic and Renaissance architecture, all in one building.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photography Locations in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: The Royal Alcazar is a beautiful palace in the heart of Seville, with many opulently decorated rooms and courtyards to explore. Of course, you can find arches, intricately carved stucco, long basins of water, geometric design, and detailed tilework throughout the palace. The picture above is the main courtyard, the Patio de las Doncellas, which is easily the most stunning part of the entire palace.
sources.shortName: 14 Gorgeous, Most Instagrammable Places in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: This is possibly the most popular tourist thing to do in the city. The Royal Alc√°zar of Seville has a beautiful blend of Moorish and Mudejar architecture, offering photographers an exquisite array of intricate details, lush gardens, and enchanting courtyards. On my visit, I really enjoyed capturing the intricate details.
sources.shortName: 5 Photo Locations in Seville

sources.snippet: The Royal Alcazar of Seville is one of the oldest active royal palaces in the world. If the King of Spain wanted to stay in the palace while visiting Seville, he could and it would be closed to tourists. The palace is a beautiful blend of Christian and Mudejar architecture and is one of the city‚Äôs most iconic monuments.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable places in Seville - OurBigJourney

sources.snippet: The Real Alc√°zar, commonly known as the Alc√°zar of Seville, is a Royal Palace constructed in the 1400s. There is a rich history behind the compound that was founded in the middle ages. The Castilians took over the grounds in the 1300s and used them for Royal Residences.
sources.shortName: a Complete Seville Itinerary

sources.snippet: The compound dates all the way back to 913 when the palace was built for Peter of Castile. The building is stunningly maintained and the perfect spot for an idyllic Seville Instagram shot. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Seville

places.name: Royal Alc√°zar of Seville

reviews.text: A seriously beautiful palace. Architecture is nothing short of amazing. The gardens are well keep, even in the heat. You can easily spend a few hours here. Enter at the lions gate. Lines moves quickly to get in. Buy timed ticket online. Water closet, cafe and gift shop inside.

Royal Alc√°zar of Seville is one of the key landmarks when visiting Seville.  We went over the August Bank holiday weekend and it was BUSY - as you'd expect, not to mention incredibly hot, both inside and out.  Take a fan and plenty of water as the place is large!  There is a cafe but we didn't use it.  There seems to be a lot of recommendations about booking in advance, but we booked at about 10pm on Saturday night and got tickets for 11.30 the next morning.  Maybe we were lucky or August is quieter... I don't know.  Book to be on the safe side - I'd recommend using a local operator if poss - prices range from ¬£50 each to ¬£17pp which we opted for!  That said, this didn't include a tour / audio. There were QR codes but didn't try those.  Nothing is in English either - just an observation.  Inside, the palace consisted of a series of interconnected rooms, mainly empty (no furniture) with the exception of beautiful mosaic floors, ceilings, walls, tapestries and plaster work, open courtyards, you get the idea.  Gardens were gorgeous.  Evidently, you can see the Royal bedrooms but have to book far in advance of your visit.

Honestly, the place is pure magic. I've seen countless pictures, but nothing prepared me for how breathtaking it is in person. The sheer amount of detail in the architecture is incredible, and you can see so much history in the different styles.

The gardens are a whole other level-they're huge and so beautiful, with hidden corners and fountains everywhere. It's the perfect escape from the city heat. I could have happily spent the entire day just wandering through them.

My biggest recommendation, especially if you're visiting in the summer, is to pre-book your tickets online. Seriously, don't even think about showing up to buy them on the day. The lines can be absolutely brutal, and you'll spend a ton of time waiting in the heat. Booking online gets you a specific time slot and lets you skip the main queue, so you can head straight to security and start exploring right away. It's the best way to make sure you get in and make the most of your visit without any stress.

places.generalDescription: Plaza de Espa√±a is a landmark square in Seville, featuring a large water feature, seats adorned with painted ceramic tiles, and an ornate pavilion. It's a great spot for families to visit, as kids can enjoy exploring the plaza while adults admire its inspiring architecture. To engage children, you can introduce them to the plaza by showing them scenes from Star Wars where it was featured.

sources.snippet: Built in 1928 for the Ibero-American Exposition 1929 by Anibal Gonzalez, it‚Äôs a great example of mixing Moorish architecture with Renaissance. The plaza has a beautifully symmetrical design, and it‚Äôs surely an incredible site for Travel, Location, architecture as well as Lifestyle Content Creators. The location is so versatile that it is a must-visit for your Instagram feed.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram spots to visit in Seville in 2023

sources.snippet: I‚Äôm not sure there are many places in the world as photogenic as Plaza de Espa√±a. It is one of the most beautiful places to visit in Andalucia and was easily my favourite place in all of Seville!. I spent hours here on two different mornings photographing it from many different angles, yet I still could‚Äôve found more compositions!
sources.shortName: üì∏ 30+ Most Instagrammable Spots in Seville Spain (2024

sources.snippet: The Plaza de Espana was probably my favorite of all the Instagramable places in Seville!. It‚Äôs popular, it gets crowded, and everyone knows about it, but it is undeniably gorgeous. Unlike many of the other sites in Seville, the Plaza de Espana is actually fairly new, having been built in 1928 for the Ibero-American Exhibition.
sources.shortName: 14 Gorgeous, Most Instagrammable Places in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: Plaza Espa√±a is definitely one of the most photogenic spots in Seville. Visited by millions of tourists every year, this stunning place offers a wide range of romantic and photogenic spots for your Instagram profile. With 269K publications, Plaza Espa√±a is, without a doubt, one of the most instagrammables places in Seville.
sources.shortName: THE 5 MOST INSTAGRAMMABLE PLACES IN SEVILLE ‚Äì Photo Tour Seville ‚Äì Things to do, activities and what to see in Seville

sources.snippet: Plaza de Espa√±a is a picturesque square filled with stunning architecture, making it a perfect spot for photography. I would argue this is the best location in Seville for photography and I got some of my favourite shots from the trip here. Sunrise is probably the best time of day as you‚Äôll have the square all to yourself.
sources.shortName: 5 Photo Locations in Seville

sources.snippet: Since the beginning of my travel blogging journey (2017), I longed to visit the Plaza de Espana. Suffice it to say, I was elated when it finally happened!. The Plaza de Espana is located inside Maria Luisi Park and was built in 1929 for the Ibero-American Exhibition.
sources.shortName: a Complete Seville Itinerary

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs just really beautiful with the colorful mosaics all over the place. All around the square you can find benches out of colored tiles, for every region in Spain one. Theis is a nice place to take a rest or make some colorful selfies.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographers guide to Sevilla
Top 14 best Instagram spots of Sevilla (Spain)

places.name: Plaza de Espa√±a

reviews.text: Magnificent! A simply amazing place to visit. Nobody wouldn't like the beautiful architectures and the smart designs. It really deserves the name of "Plaza de Espa√±a", it truly shows how grand an empire was and how brilliant the people were. Visited twice, both in the morning and the evening, and both breathtakingly beautiful. I really like the fountain, not a big fan of the horse carts though. In general really a landmark and nice place you wouldn't want to miss when in Seville.

The amounts spent on these construction projects are just mind-blowing. And when you remember how many people lost their health or even died there, it gets uncomfortable.

1. Tourists today admire the marble, the gold, the columns-but for someone, all this cost a life. Nobody remembers the names of the workers, though nothing would exist without them.

2. Sometimes I look at these buildings and think: was all this beauty really worth those sacrifices? For some, it's a symbol of the nation, but for others, it's years and strength lost.

Honestly, I'm always a bit envious of the architects of that time-to plan something on this scale takes real talent. But at the same time, I feel for those who paid for this ‚Äúeternity‚Äù with their health.

I can't feel just one way about it. The architecture is impressive, but the price was enormous. Sometimes you look at a cathedral and realize there's a heavy shadow behind all that beauty.

What about you? Can you just admire places like these, or do you also think about the price?

Plaza de Espa√±a is one of Seville's most iconic landmarks and an absolute must-see. Located in Mar√≠a Luisa Park, the square combines Renaissance Revival and Moorish architecture, creating a stunning and unique atmosphere.

The semi-circular building, the tiled bridges, and the beautiful canal make the place feel like a dream. Each Spanish province is represented through colourful ceramic tiles, adding cultural depth to beauty.

Whether you rent a boat, take photos, or just walk around and admire the views,the music , the flamingo. the experience is unforgettable-especially at sunset. It's peaceful, grand, and full of charm.

places.address: Av. Isabel la Cat√≥lica, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Parque de Mar√≠a Luisa is a significant urban park in Seville, offering scenic plazas with landscaped gardens, fountains, and monuments. The park is part of an area that includes various notable landmarks such as the Giralda, the Cathedral, Reales Alcazares, Torre del Oro, Plaza de Espa√±a, and more. It's a must-visit destination in Seville and provides a comprehensive insight into the essence of the city.

sources.snippet: Only a short walk from Santa Cruz, stretching along the Guadalquivir River, is Seville‚Äôs main public park. Most of the grounds of Maria Luisa Park were formerly a private garden, part of the Palace of San Telmo, but they were so beautiful that, in the late 1800s, they opened to the public. Today, this oasis, which spans 34 hectares, is a favourite of locals and tourists alike with its tree-lined walkways, flower gardens and wildlife.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Seville

sources.snippet: The Parque de Mar√≠a Luisa, with the Plaza de Espa√±a at its center, was the site of the Exposici√≥n Iberoamericana in 1929. This expansive green space was created for the Infanta Mar√≠a Luisa Fernanda de Borb√≥n, who donated it to the city of Seville in 1893. The lush 34-hectare park flourishes alongside the river, with its exotic palms, orange trees, elms, and Mediterranean pines.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

sources.snippet: This park stretches just behind the Plaza de Espana and with its lush flower gardens and beautiful tree shaded paths, it‚Äôs the perfect place to wander around with a camera in hand. In spring when everything is in full blooms, it‚Äôs especially beautiful. The park has a small lake with a few ducks, and if you‚Äôre travelling with kids, they will love it here.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photography Locations in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: With its lush greenery and tranquil atmosphere, Parque de Mar√≠a Luisa is a serene oasis in the heart of Seville. I really enjoyed walking around this park and I couldn‚Äôt quite believe how many orange trees there were. The highlight for me in terms of photography was the Museum of Popular Arts and Traditions, particularly during the blue hour light.
sources.shortName: 5 Photo Locations in Seville

sources.snippet: Right across the street from the Plaza Espana is Parque Maria Luisa. Like Park Retiro in Madrid, this lush, jaw-dropping park was once part of the palace grounds, but was turned into a public space in the early 1900s when the Ibero-American Exposition and World Fair came to Seville. It‚Äôs been impeccably maintained ever since.
sources.shortName: 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Seville (2024)

sources.snippet: One of Seville‚Äôs largest green spaces is Mar√≠a Luisa Park, right beside Plaza de Espa√±a. Here you‚Äôll find all kinds of lush backdrops as well as picture-perfect colorful tiles. And don‚Äôt miss the tucked-away Mud√©jar Pavilion, another An√≠bal Gonz√°lez creation, which doesn‚Äôt get the credit or attention it deserves.
sources.shortName: 10 Instagrammable Spots in Seville to Give All Your Followers Major FOMO

sources.snippet: Mar√≠a Luisa is a large park in the center of Seville right next to the famous landmark square Plaza de Espa√±a. At first, you might think there can‚Äôt be anything too special about a park. However, this one hides some very beautiful hidden gems and some of my favorite Instagram spots in Seville!
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: This is the largest park in the city centre ‚Äì and the most ornate park in Seville. You‚Äôll find various ponds with fountains, charming bridges, pergolas covered in flowers and beautiful pavilions. The park also has a diverse mix of flora, including fragrant roses and towering palms.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: A lush park with lots of shaded areas and places to stretch out with a good book or the company of a good friend. The park runs along the river so there‚Äôs lots of scenic places to snap a Seville Instagram photo. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Seville
The Most Instagrammable Photo Spots in Seville, Spain

places.name: Parque de Mar√≠a Luisa

reviews.text: Stunning well kept park, perfect place to relax and listen to the bird song.  Beautiful gardens, water fountains, and statues right next to the Plaza de Espa√±a, you can get a tram from the city centre, highly recommended.

Beautiful park right next to the Plaza de Espa√±a. We went there for a quiet stroll after visiting the Plaza de Espa√±a.

In the park you can find shade, made beautiful trees, plants and a wide variety of animals.

We also enjoyed the art in the park and the quiet sounds of the trees, the bushes and the animals.

Go there if you want a quiet break in the warm city.

The park is so beautiful and lovely! I simply enjoyed the vibe here and had a wonderful time just taking a morning walk in it. You can feel the balanced mixture of nature and human in this place, all the colors and cool architectures are also making visiting this place a unique experience. Definitely recommend to come and visit, such a nice place to chill and relax.

places.generalDescription: La Giralda is a stunning Spanish Renaissance-style minaret with a Gothic and baroque bell tower. It's part of the diverse and beautiful monuments in Seville, including the Cathedral, Reales Alcazares, Torre del Oro, Plaza de Espana, Maria Luisa Park, and more. Seville offers an array of tourism options from historical tours to tapas and wine tours.

sources.snippet: Put simply, La Giralda is the name of the Bell Tower attached to Seville Cathedral, it was built in Moorish times as the Minaret for the Great Mosque of Seville. La Giralda was registered in 1987 as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO and remains one of the tallest churches in the world. Visitors who are able to walk the steep 35 ramps to the top of the Bell Tower are greeted with panoramic views of the City.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Photo Spots in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: La Giralda in Seville is one of the most Instagrammable spots of Seville, known for its stunning blend of Moorish and Renaissance architecture. Its elegant design, intricate details, and panoramic city views from the top make it a popular photography subject. Capture the tower‚Äôs beauty, ascend its ramps, and enjoy the picturesque surroundings of the Plaza de los Naranjos for a memorable Instagram shot.
sources.shortName: 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Seville (2024)

sources.snippet: La Giralda is the name of one of the main symbols of Seville ‚Äì the bell tower of the Cathedral of Seville. It was built in the 12th century as a minaret for a mosque during the Islamic period in Andalusia. Later when the territory was ruled by the Catholics, and many buildings around the city were redesigned for Christians, the top part with church bells was added to the tower.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: La Giralda is what sevillanos call to the tower of the Cathedral because of the statue on the top, which is called Giraldillo. This tower is the most important, and popular, part of the Cathedral. With 98 height meters, this arabic-construction is the real treasure of Seville and one of the most instagrammable spots of Seville.
sources.shortName: THE 5 MOST INSTAGRAMMABLE PLACES IN SEVILLE ‚Äì Photo Tour Seville ‚Äì Things to do, activities and what to see in Seville

sources.snippet: La Giralda is an iconic symbol of Seville, rising majestically above the city. This area is very busy during the day but by venturing there before and during sunrise, you can have the place all to yourself. I went to this area with no single image in mind but I used La Giralda as a focal point in the images I was capturing.
sources.shortName: 5 Photo Locations in Seville

sources.snippet: This is the Belltower of Seville‚Äôs Cathedral; you will see this building from Kilometres. It is not just a religious place, but it is becoming one of Seville‚Äôs photo spots nowadays. In 1184, this tower was the highest in the World and now is the best example of Almohad architecture in Spain.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable Seville | The Best Photography Guide Of Andalusia

sources.snippet: Located directly in the city center, the Seville Cathedral is one of the largest in the world. The architecture outside is spectacular and even more impressive inside. The views from the top of the bell tower (La Giralda) are some of the best of the entire Seville skyline.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Most Instagrammable places in Seville 2019 | by Lucas Garcia

sources.snippet: The name of the belltower of Seville Cathedral is La Giralda. The architecture style on the Koutoubia in Marrakesh, it does bear a clear resemblance.
sources.shortName: Photogenic Seville & its most instagrammable spots

places.name: La Giralda

reviews.text: We did the 20.30 roof tour and it's absolutely fantastic. Did not except that we were able to see this much of one of the greatest and most beautiful monuments of Spain. Very kind and knowledged guide, good working head sets. Very fair price if you see what you get. Would recommend to everyone who can climb a few narrow stairs (you go up all the way).

Climbing the tower is optional on a visit to the cathedral. It's a sloped path - not stairs which helped make it feel easier. There are a lot of level window nooks with flat seating for when you need a break. It would say it's moderately steep, but doable, especially because there are opportunities to rest. The up/down traffic is on the same path which made it a bit crowded in places. But the view at the top is beautiful. The frequent windows did let in some fresh air and slight breeze, but it was pretty warm in early June about noon.

Majestic and timeless, Seville Cathedral and the Giralda offer an unforgettable experience. After admiring the vast Gothic interior, visitors face a demanding ascent. While the official description highlights ramps and a few steps, the full route - including upper levels and the rooftop perimeter - amounts to more than 300 steps. In Seville's heat, it is wise to carry water, wear comfortable shoes, and avoid peak hours. The effort is richly rewarded with breathtaking views and a profound sense of Seville's historic soul.

places.address: Av. de la Constituci√≥n, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Metropol Parasol, also known as Las Setas or the Mushrooms of Seville, is a unique and avant-garde wooden structure built in 2011. Its design resembles six large mushrooms or umbrellas, standing out from the traditional Andalusian architecture in Seville. This iconic attraction features a panoramic terrace, a walking path, and an archaeological museum.

sources.snippet: Metropol Parasol or Las Setas on the Plaza de la Encarnaci√≥n (by English speaking people known as the mushroom) is a modern architecture wood construction. The building looks really cool and you can take nice photos at night when it‚Äôs light up in various colors. The coolest thing about the mushroom is that you can get on top.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographers guide to Sevilla

sources.snippet: Metropol Parasol is a wooden structure located at La Encarnaci√≥n square. It‚Äôs populary known as Las Setas de la Encarnaci√≥n (Incarnation‚Äôs mushrooms) and its appearance and location resulted in much public controversy. I personally love it!
sources.shortName: Most instagrammable places in Seville

places.name: Setas de Sevilla

reviews.text: Largest wooden structure in the world apparently.  Fascinating piece of architecture which you can walk up inside and round the top.  Interesting film show about Seville.  Good views over the city during the day and the ticket includes a second visit in the evening to see it all lit up.  Worth going back for! Lovely cafes & restaurants in the area.  Large free seating area within the attraction.  One of the highlights of Seville.

A great place to view the whole of Seville. This modern structure stands out in its surroundings and is an amazing piece of architecture.
Amazingly helpful staff and great audio guide provided on your walk around the skyline walkways.
Was a little disappointed with the lights in the dark. Feel like they need to invest in bulb replacement schedule, lots of areas not lit up.

Love the look of the design and was pleasantly surprised at how well the structure fitted into the surroundings.  We went up for sunset which was beautiful, but be prepared for it to get quite busy and people taking up loads of space. Unfortunately we couldn't wait for it to get dark to see the light show from the top but we did return the following evening and watched it from the ground.  The lights looked lovely from below but from videos I've watched you really need to see them from above. A definite must visit when in Seville.

places.address: Pl. de la Encarnaci√≥n, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41003 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Catedral de Sevilla is a grand Gothic cathedral in Spain, known for its iconic Moorish bell tower offering stunning city views and housing Columbus' tomb. The cathedral is part of the Barrio Santa Cruz, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that also includes Real Alcazar and Archivo General de Indias. This historic neighborhood is filled with rich cultural landmarks like the Hospital de los Venerables Sacerdotes and flamenco tablaos.

sources.snippet: As the world's largest Gothic cathedral, this monument is unmatched in its impressive scale and abundance of art treasures. Listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this glorious place of worship was constructed between 1402 and 1506 on the site of the town's principal mosque. The cathedral's bell tower, La Giralda, was originally the minaret of the mosque built in the 12th century by Moorish rulers of the Almohad dynasty.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

sources.snippet: The Seville Cathedral is the largest Gothic cathedral in the world and the third-largest church in the world. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site too.Originally it was a mosque in the 12th Century, then a Christian church before being converted to the Cathedral we see today. Interesting fact: It is also the home of Christopher Columbus‚Äôs tomb, it was transferred here from Havana, Cuba during the Cuban revolution of 1902.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram spots to visit in Seville in 2023

sources.snippet: Whether you take your Seville Cathedral photos from the outside, inside or on the roof, you won‚Äôt be disappointed. Catedral de Sevilla is one of the world‚Äôs grandest Gothic cathedrals and the largest cathedral by volume. Inside,  you‚Äôll find elaborate carvings, towering pillars, and stained glass windows.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: The Seville Cathedral is a magnificent gothic church located in the heart of the city. It is the largest gothic cathedral in the world and the third-largest church in the world, as well as being a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Oh, and it‚Äôs beautiful, with both Muslim and Christian influence on the design.
sources.shortName: üì∏ 30+ Most Instagrammable Spots in Seville Spain (2024

sources.snippet: Also steps from the hotel: the Catedral de Sevilla, which was rebuilt in a Gothic style in the 16th century. The cathedral is gigantic (it has the longest nave in Spain), and preserves some of the Islamic architectural features of its previous incarnation as a mosque.
sources.siteName: La Carmina Blog - Alternative Goth Fashion, Travel, Subcultures
sources.shortName: Seville, Spain top photography spots! Setas de Sevilla architecture, Hotel Dona Maria, 5 Senses food & flamenco. | La Carmina Blog

sources.snippet: The Cathedral of Seville is a landmark attraction in the city of Seville and in Andalusia. It is recognized by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site. The cathedral is one of the largest churches in the world and the largest Gothic church in the world.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

places.name: Catedral de Sevilla

reviews.text:
The cathedral is definitely worth a visit, not only for its impressive history but also for its striking architecture. It's a grand and opulent building, though it does lack a bit of character and intimacy.
A particularly interesting feature is the tomb of Christopher Columbus. The highlight, however, is the bell tower, which offers a fantastic panoramic view of the city.
Restrooms and water dispensers are available, and it's recommended to buy your tickets in advance.

Seville Cathedral is the largest Gothic cathedral in the world and it's over the top AMAZING! Once inside, it feels almost otherworldly. Unbelievable ceilings, artwork, golden alters, individual ornate chapels and so much more! It seems to go on forever. This chapel is a photographer's dream!

The tomb of Christopher Columbus was fascinating to me. I've never seen anything like it. The craftsmanship of the monument is remarkable.

There is an opportunity to climb La Giralda bell tower too. Instead of stairs, they have ramps that make it easier than expected. The panoramic views over Seville's rooftops are breathtaking from above!

Its smart to book tickets early and to plan on taking your time inside. There's a lot to see and appreciate. A truly iconic landmark!!

Visiting Catedral de Sevilla was an awe-inspiring experience! üåü The sheer scale of the cathedral left us speechless - it's one of the largest and most magnificent churches we've ever seen. Walking inside felt like stepping back in time, surrounded by incredible Gothic architecture, intricate details, and a peaceful, almost spiritual atmosphere. Even though we didn't go up La Giralda, just exploring the interior was unforgettable. The light streaming through the stained glass windows created a magical glow that added to the beauty. ‚õ™ A true masterpiece and a highlight of Seville that we'll never forget!

places.address: Av. de la Constituci√≥n, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Plaza de Toros de la Real Maestranza de Caballer√≠a de Sevilla, also known as La Maestranza, is a historic bullring dating back to 1761. It is the oldest bullfighting ring in the world and remains in use for traditional bullfights during the annual Seville Fair. The site also houses a museum showcasing the art of bullfighting.

sources.snippet: The Real Maestranza de Caballer√≠a de Sevilla (Royal Bullring of Seville) is one of the finest bullrings in Spain, and with seating for around 12,500 spectators, it is also one of the largest. Built in 1761, the Royal Bullring is an emblematic landmark of Seville. The design is distinctly Baroque, with an oval-shaped ring that makes it unique among Spanish bullrings, and its graceful arcaded seating provides welcome shade on sunny days.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

sources.snippet: Plaza de Toros is a bullfighting arena in Seville that has been officially declared as a Site of Cultural Interest. It is the third most visited sight in Seville. Through a tour you can see the Plaza de Toros from the inside and take a nice picture in the middle of the bullring!.
sources.shortName: Tip: 10 best Instagram & photo spots in Andalucia
Instagrammable Seville | The Best Photography Guide Of Andalusia

places.name: Plaza de Toros de la Real Maestranza de Caballer√≠a de Sevilla

reviews.text:
Visited here to learn about the culture of bullfighting. Learnt that it's one of a handful of Bullrings that still operate as one. This one has a lovely museum and art gallery, can even walk up into the stands and view the arena. If you want to learn about culture and history you should visit here.

We didn't have to queue to get in, bought tickets online. Used Google lens to translate information.

Really enjoyed this. Really, no crowd, as we had not made reservations. Did self guided tour. The only downside was I was with 3 other individuals that all tried to download the audio tour, and none of us had success. It was on a qr code. Still was a very interesting part of not only bullfighting history but also of the community. This is one that is still in operation. For someone who really has no interest, I might recommend missing it. I really wanted to understand more of history, and that was accomplished. My favorite part was being in the areana. We used google Translate to read a number of the document inside so that we may understand them. Was well worth the time and money.

What a wonderful visit, well worth stopping by. It cost 12Euros to get in.   I bought ticket at the arena.   Audio guide on several languages that you can listen to, so headphones/air pods help.  Some really neat photo opportunities to take selfies or a group photo.

Later in the day you get some shade if you want to sit in the stands, and view the arena from uo high!!

places.address: P.¬∫ de Crist√≥bal Col√≥n, 12, Casco Antiguo, 41001 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Seville, the Iglesia Colegial del Divino Salvador stands as a remarkable symbol of the city‚Äôs rich tapestry of history and architecture. Originally constructed as a mosque during the reign of Abd al Rahman II, this stunning Baroque Roman Catholic church showcases an impressive array of intricate details and artistic flair. As you step inside, you're greeted by soaring ceilings that create an atmosphere of grandeur, complemented by elaborate altarpieces and beautifully carved sculptures adorning its nave.

sources.snippet: A short walk from the cathedral, the Iglesia Colegial del Divino Salvador is a stunningly beautiful Baroque church. Construction began in the late 17th century on the site where La Mezquita Aljama de Ibn Adabb√°s, Seville's old mosque, once stood, and many additions have taken place since this time. Glowing pink in the late afternoon light, the ornate facade is influenced by the Mannerist style.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

places.name: Iglesia Colegial del Divino Salvador

reviews.text: Wow! We visited this church after our cathedral visit since it was included in the ticket.  What an amazing place, and there were very few other visitors.  The intricate carvings are highlighted by colored lights from the stained glass that gradually moved across the walls and floors. There is a crypt area below that details the history of the city and the church which is well curated. Highly recommend!

Impressive interior. Very rich decorations. Water spring underneath the church (in crypt). It would most likely be much more remarkable and popular if it wouldn't be located meters away from Seville Cathedral and Giralda. Think it's very underrated while it have a lot to offer simply because it was the main Seville church between regaining the city from Arabs till funds from America started to arrive, so Cathedral could be rebuilt into its today's shape. If you buy tickets for the Cathedral directly from their website, you won't have to pay for entry. If you done / are about to do guided tour of Cathedral and Giralda, then you'll have to pay 7‚Ç¨ to enter (I don't regret it at all).

This church (especially the museum underneath!) was really interesting. Don't skip the crypt/basement. There is a ton of seating in the church to rest your feet and it was peaceful. Remember to cover your shoulders if you are a woman.

places.address: Pl. del Salvador, 3, Casco Antiguo, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Setas de Sevilla, also known as Las Setas, is a striking and modern architectural installation in Seville. Designed by German architect Jurgen Mayer, it is recognized as the world's largest wooden structure. The mushroom-shaped parasol offers visitors the opportunity to explore an archaeological museum and take in panoramic views of the city from its rooftop walkway and viewpoint.

sources.snippet: Las Setas de Seville is a large, modern, ‚Äúmushroom‚Äù-shaped installation, where you can walk underneath the ‚Äúparasol‚Äù roof, or go up to the roof for a cool and unique view over Seville‚Äôs rooftops. There‚Äôs a small pathway to walk around the perimeter of the parasol, giving you many vantage points over the city. The best time to visit Las Setas is indubitably right before sunset, as watching the sky get all aglow and then darken over Sevilla is absolutely gorgeous, and makes for a great photo spot in Seville.
sources.shortName: 14 Gorgeous, Most Instagrammable Places in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: The Setas de Sevilla, colloquially dubbed ‚ÄòThe Mushrooms‚Äô represents a striking juxtaposition of contemporary urban design amidst the rich tapestry of Seville‚Äôs historical charm. I paid a quick visit to Setas de Sevilla, and I really enjoyed capturing some abstract images of the unique textures and patterns. If I had another day in the city, I would have headed here for sunrise and during the blue hour to capture more of the surrounding area.
sources.shortName: 5 Photo Locations in Seville

sources.snippet: To photograph the wooden structure itself, you need to stand underneath it and use a very wide angle lens to capture as much of it as possible, although likely not all of it, or a less wide lens to focus on parts of it. I prefer to photograph this view during blue hour, when the blue lights of the structure match the sky and everything is illuminated.
sources.shortName: 8 Best Photography Spots in Seville

sources.snippet: The ancient history of Sevilla is reflected everywhere in its architecture, but the city also has room for modern, forward-thinking buildings. One of them is Setas de Sevilla, an eye-catching wooden structure in the form of a parasol. Initially, it was called Metropol Parasol, but the name changed because everyone thought it looked like a mushroom.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Seville

sources.snippet: Las Setas de Sevilla (Mushrooms of Seville), or also known as the Metropol Parasol, is a large wooden structure located in the old city center, at Plaza de la Encarnaci√≥n. The monument sticks out above the old buildings, and many say is an eye sore and insult to the architecture of the town. I will let you be the judge of that.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photography Locations in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: I experienced the best of the culture thanks to Sevilla City Centre, which has a ‚Äú5 Senses‚Äù customizable tour package for visitors. Our concierge was wonderful at arranging experiences for us over What‚Äôs App ‚Äî including tapas restaurants, a flamenco show, transfers, and more.
sources.siteName: La Carmina Blog - Alternative Goth Fashion, Travel, Subcultures
sources.shortName: Seville, Spain top photography spots! Setas de Sevilla architecture, Hotel Dona Maria, 5 Senses food & flamenco. | La Carmina Blog

sources.snippet: Setas de Sevilla, otherwise known as Metropol Parasol, is the largest wooden structure in the world that overlooks Seville City. The structure is composed of six parasols in the form of a mushroom. Because of this, the locals deemed it ‚ÄòThe Mushroom‚Äô.
sources.shortName: a Complete Seville Itinerary

sources.snippet: The Food Market Mercado de la Encarnacion is also known as ¬¥Las Setas¬¥ (mushrooms in english). This modern parasol above the market is the largest wooden structure in the world. It is also a great vantage point to see Seville from above.
sources.shortName: Photogenic Seville & its most instagrammable spots

sources.snippet: This is said to be one of the largest wooden structures in the world. It‚Äôs definitely an interesting piece of architecture. It can be admired from the streets, or you can pay an entrance fee to access different areas of the structure.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable places in Seville - OurBigJourney

sources.snippet: Setas de Sevilla is an architectural masterpiece in the heart of Seville city. It is a massive wooden structure in the shape of mushrooms (‚Äòsetas‚Äô in Spanish).
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

places.name: Setas de Sevilla

reviews.text:
The Setas de Sevilla is a really cool and unique landmark. It's this huge, modern wooden structure right in the middle of a historic square, and I loved the contrast. It's a great place to just hang out below, grab a drink, and people-watch.

The best part, though, is going up to the top. The walkway is so fun to wander around, and you get some of the most amazing panoramic views of the city. Seeing all the rooftops and landmarks from a different perspective is a great experience. I went just before sunset, and the golden light over Seville was absolutely magical. It's a great spot for photos and a nice way to end the day.

It has a unique design and is quite an interesting place. It's a good spot to sit and relax in the morning or early afternoon, and it looks beautiful in the evening with the lighting. The area is generally lively. You can go up with a ticket and walk around, but I haven't tried it.

A great place to view the whole of Seville. This modern structure stands out in its surroundings and is an amazing piece of architecture.
Amazingly helpful staff and great audio guide provided on your walk around the skyline walkways.
Was a little disappointed with the lights in the dark. Feel like they need to invest in bulb replacement schedule, lots of areas not lit up.

places.address: Pl. de la Encarnaci√≥n, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41003 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Murillo Gardens is a serene urban park in Seville, featuring well-maintained pathways, shaded seating areas, and historic monuments. It's part of the must-visit attractions in Seville, along with other iconic landmarks like Reales Alcazares and the Cathedral of Seville. The gardens are named after the 17th-century painter Murillo and offer a peaceful retreat from the city's hustle and bustle.

sources.snippet: With such stunning and vast gardens nearby as those in the Royal Alc√°zar of Seville, the Murillo Gardens often get overlooked. If you have seen the Alcazar, it may seem you have seen the most beautiful spots in Seville, however, I beg to differ. Murillo Gardens is a long stretch of gardens with fountains, beautiful trees, benches hiding in the shade, and other architectural ornaments hidden in the lush green area.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: Named after renowned painter Bartolom√© Esteban Murillo, this city garden shares a wall with the Alcazar Gardens. Murillo Gardens is a much more regimental park than Maria Luisa. Paths follow a grid-like pattern but are separated by planted areas.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

places.name: Murillo Gardens

reviews.text: FIVE STARS ‚Äì Beautiful greenery and wide spaces to slow down and walk comfortably in the city... Interesting monuments, as this one depicting Christopher Columbus' ship, the Santa Maria, named after Queen Isabella.
Beautiful garden, most people use this path to get to another side of the palace

An excellent urban park.  Both shaded and sunny, well-maintained paths for strolling suitable for wheeled travelers (strollers and wheelchair users).  Stately trees - palms, Ficus and others.  Lots of songbirds.  A play area for children and lots of benches for resting, relaxing, and chatting. Worth a visit as part of a tour of the area around the Alcazar.

March 30, 2025
C & J

places.address: Av. de Men√©ndez Pelayo, Casco Antiguo, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Casa de Pilatos is a stunning palace located at no 1, Plaza de Pilatos, dating back to the fifteenth century. It was created through the union of two noble families and reflects their love for Renaissance art. The palace features internal courtyards adorned with Greek and Roman statues, as well as an impressive collection of artworks. Over time, it underwent comprehensive remodeling that incorporated Romantic elements and features.

sources.snippet: If you don‚Äôt have time to visit any other spot, I would suggest visiting this one, there are many different angles to choose from as this is the most Instagrammable spot in Seville.It is a perfect example of an archetypal Andalusian palace with a mix of Italian Renaissance and Spanish Mudejar style. Home to one of the largest collections of azulejos in the world, it boasts around 150 types of colourful ceramic tyles. Photo tip: Casa de Pilatos isn‚Äôt as popular as the other spots, hence it does not get that busy.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram spots to visit in Seville in 2023

sources.snippet: Casa de Pilatos is another palatial home that visitors can explore, and is a great, yet underrated photo spot in Seville. The Casa de Pilatos is very similar to the Las Duenos Palace in that it has a large courtyard surrounded by columns and archways, but Casa de Pilatos was just a little more ‚Äúhomey‚Äù, with warmer colors. The courtyards had more greenery, the walls were painted in warm yellows and reds, and these beautiful tapestries hung on the walls.
sources.shortName: 14 Gorgeous, Most Instagrammable Places in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: While not quite as opulent as the Real Alcaz√°r, Casa de Pilatos is definitely a must-see in Seville. Dating back to the 15th-century, it provides a perfect example of an archetypal Andalusian palace with a flawless mix of Italian Rennaisance and Spanish Mudejar style. It is also home to one of the largest collections of azulejos in the world, with around 150 of the colourful ceramic tiles.
sources.shortName: üì∏ 30+ Most Instagrammable Spots in Seville Spain (2024

sources.snippet: Cada de Pilatos in Seville ‚Äì the finest example of traditional Andalusian architecture and the prototype of an Andalusian palace. During the 16th century, Seville was known as ‚Äòthe new Rome‚Äô and this palace is truly a testament to that. The palace has a mix of Renaissance and Spanish Mudejar styles in the 15th century, with Gothic elements added later on.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photography Locations in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: The Casa de Pilatos (Palace of the Governors of Andalusia) is a designated National Monument. This exquisite palace was once the private residence of the aristocratic Enr√≠quez de Ribera family, including the Dukes of Alcal√°. Built in the 15th and 16th centuries, the Casa de Pilatos is believed to be a replica of Pilate's house in Jerusalem.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

sources.snippet: One of the most stunning royal palaces of Spain and best Seville Instagram spots, Casa de Pilatos is my favorite!. A bit of a hidden gem, this sumptuous 16th-century mansion in Seville‚Äôs historic district is totally swoon-worthy. It‚Äôs about a 15-minute walk from the Seville Cathedral.
sources.shortName: 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Seville (2024)

sources.snippet: Casa de Pilatos is an Andalusia palace built in the 16th Century. It was built in the 16th century by the Dukes of Medinaceli and is one of the most impressive examples of Mudejar architecture in the city. It‚Äôs a much smaller scale than Real Alcazar but just as intricately detailed.
sources.shortName: a Complete Seville Itinerary

sources.snippet: Another one of the best Seville Instagrammable locations is Casa de Pilatos. This Andalusian palace blends Renaissance, Mudejar, and Gothic styles. Similar to the Alcazar, every surface is covered with colourful azulejos (tiles) and intricate details that make every shot pop.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: Casa de Pilatos is a 16th-century palace located in the historic part of Seville‚Äôs city center. The jewel of this place is the main courtyard. It blends together Gothic, Mudejar, Renaissance, and Romantic elements through statues, archways, marble, and colorful tiles.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: The Casa de Pilatos is one of the many privately owned city palaces that can be found in Sevilla. It is one of the bigger ones with the main patio and a few gardens. Especially beautiful are the many different tiles all around the palace (150 different types!).
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographers guide to Sevilla

sources.snippet: Casa de Pilatos is a palace in Seville that is another fine example of Andalusian architecture. It is l ess visited than some of the other bigger sites in Seville. Therefore, you can go pretty much any time of day and get some nice photos if you‚Äôre patient.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable places in Seville - OurBigJourney

sources.snippet: Casa de Pilatos is an Andalusian palace and is a permanent residence. It has Mud√©jar elements and has around 150 different azulejos (colored tiles). Next to taking pretty pictures on the gram, you can learn a little about the history of this nice palace.
sources.shortName: Top 14 best Instagram spots of Sevilla (Spain)

sources.snippet: Casa de Pilatos is a palace that dates back to the 15th century and is located in the historic center of Seville. The palace is similar to the Real Alc√°zar, but smaller. You‚Äôll find cute patios here and the walls are filled with beautiful mosaics!.
sources.shortName: Tip: 10 best Instagram & photo spots in Andalucia

sources.snippet: It means more unique photos and more space for coming up with those creative ideas. Seville has so much to offer. My advice is: consider these suggestions, but also explore and get lost in the surprising photo moments of this beautiful city.
sources.shortName: Most instagrammable places in Seville

places.name: Casa de Pilatos

reviews.text: The architecture, mosaics, sculptures and gardens of this palace is world class and very unique. A must visit for everyone who enjoy aesthetics as well as art history. We spent a long time here to enjoy all the different rooms and outdoor areas.

This is a less known site however worth visiting. It has beautifully preserved palace blending various styles including Gothic and Renaissance architecture. Beautiful courtyards filled with delicate art and various statues. A lot to see and we were not able to see the upstairs residence rooms. Has a nice garden and a lot of corners to take photos.

I thought it would be much smaller than it was! Walked in when passing by and saw that it might be a nice stop but it was so much more! Lots of rooms and courtyards to explore. Allow time to walk around and appreciate the effort put into creating such a special place. Provides a glimpse into the history that shaped this blend of art and cultural styles.

places.address: Pl. de Pilatos, 1, Casco Antiguo, 41003 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: The Palacio de las Due√±as, a grand palace dating back to the late 1400s, offers a fascinating glimpse into Andalusian aristocratic life. Over the centuries, it has been home to notable figures such as Empress Eugenie de Montijo and Alfonso XIII, as well as serving as a residence for famous guests like Jacqueline Kennedy and Grace Kelly.

sources.snippet: The Las Duenas Palace is a gorgeous palace in Seville that combines Renaissance, Moorish, and Gothic design features and is a stunningly beautiful place to visit. The combination of the different architectural styles makes for a rich and unique experience, with traditional Renaissance features like the marble flooring and the Roman sculptures with Moorish elements like colorful, detailed mosaics and intricately carved stucco on the arches around the palace. Besides the main courtyard, there are several other gardens and courtyards, as well as interior rooms that feature opulent furnishings and beautiful tapestries.
sources.shortName: 14 Gorgeous, Most Instagrammable Places in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: Like the architecture in the Real Alc√°zar, this palace is quite magnificent and offers many areas for photo opportunities. Each patio is lined with intrinsic arches and beautiful plants, creating a variety of colors for an esthetically pleasing photo. Just like the Real Alc√°zar, Palacio de las Due√±as can get very busy, so we recommend going earlier in the day to beat the chaos and ensure you get the best photos!
sources.shortName: Top 8 Most Instagrammable places in Seville 2019 | by Lucas Garcia

sources.snippet: Palacio de las Duenas is one of the most beautiful places in Seville. Built between the 15th and 16th centuries, this series of courtyards and buildings mixes Gothic, Moorish and Renaissance styles with typical Sevillian elements in the bricks, roof tiles, wall tiles and ceramics. The palace used to be the favourite home of a notorious Spanish aristocrat, the Duchess de Alba.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Seville

sources.snippet: Las Due√±as is one of the finest examples of Andalusian architecture, combining Moorish, Rennaisance, and Gothic influences. It was built in the 16th century and it is considered to be of great architectural and historic heritage. Palacio de las Due√±as is a short walk away from  Casa de Pilatos, so you can easily visit these two in one day.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photography Locations in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: Palacio de las Due√±as is a 15th-century palace featuring a very rich collection of art pieces from around the world. This massive complex consists of multiple palace buildings, patios, and stunning gardens with blooming trees and water systems. In my humble opinion, this palace is one of the most beautiful places in Seville.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: If you want to see inside an Analucian home from a bygone era, then include Palacio de las Due√±as in your Seville itinerary. This is the former residence of the Duke and Duchess of Alba. It is both an artistic and architectural gem with its tapestry-filled rooms, ornate furniture, and old paintings.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: It is smaller then Casa de Pilatos but offers a beautiful garden and Patio. Especially in spring when everything is blooming the main facade (that can also be seen from outside) looks incredible. The Patio Principal is a perfect place to get a rest from walking through the city the whole day.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographers guide to Sevilla

sources.snippet: Another incredible Sevillian palace, Las Duenas is a hidden gem filled with stunning staterooms, courtyards, gardens, and fountains. Former occupants include Queen Victoria, Jackie Kennedy and Grace Kelly. Surprisingly, this spot was actually pretty empty when I visited.
sources.shortName: 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Seville (2024)

sources.snippet: Built in the 15th century this palatial home belongs to the House of Alba. Although it wasn¬¥t opened to the public until 2016, it is now one of the most popular tourist locations in Seville. Get your Skip the Line tickets for Palacio de las Due√±as
sources.shortName: Photogenic Seville & its most instagrammable spots

sources.snippet: Hey, I‚Äôm not complaining royalty has always been intriguing to me. Palacio de Las Duenas was built between the 15th and 16th centuries. And has been the residence of various aristocratic families over the years.
sources.shortName: a Complete Seville Itinerary

places.name: Palacio de las Due√±as

reviews.text: We spent a truly wonderful afternoon at Palacio de las Due√±as. It was our first time visiting, and it came highly recommended as one of Seville's hidden gems and it did not disappoint. The palace is full of charm and history, with beautiful architecture, peaceful gardens, and fascinating exhibitions that give insight into Seville's noble past. There is an entrance fee, but it's absolutely worth it for the experience. If you're looking for a quieter, less crowded spot in the city that still offers rich culture and beauty, this place is a must-visit.

Lovely Palace. Much quieter than other places, which makes the visit even more pleasant. The patios are beautiful and refreshing. You can either use their online audio guide or on site they will provide you one.

Wonderful self guided tour!!  Plan to take about 45 minutes.  It has an audio guide you can listen to in multiple languages. You can access via your phone or the gift shop has devices you can use for this purpose.  A neat act is that someone actually lives in the building. He doesn't have much meaning for them or seeing them.   I believe the cost was roughly 14 euros.  I recommend doing the audio tour as you go through. You can skip ahead at any time, the rooms are numbered so you know which audio to select. There was some minor road construction leading to the palace, but there are signs to ensure that you can find your way

places.address: C. Due√±as, 5, Casco Antiguo, 41003 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Seville is a city with an abundance of beautiful and historic landmarks, including the Torre del Oro. This outer defensive tower, built around 1220, has a name that sparks various theories about its origins. The city also boasts other must-see attractions such as the Giralda, the Cathedral of Seville, Reales Alcazares (Arabic Palace), and many more.

sources.snippet: Another iconic Sevillian landmark is La Torre del Oro, or, in English, the Golden Tower, a 36-metre-high structure that sits right next to the river. The tower, one of the most photographed sites in the city, was built in the 12th century for military observation with the function of safeguarding the Guadalquivir. Interestingly, a heavy chain ran underwater straight from the huge tower to the other bank to block enemy ships from entering the city.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Seville

sources.snippet: The Torre del Oro is a 13th century watchtower that sits on the banks of the Guadalquivir River in Seville. While there is a museum inside and a viewing platform at the top, I think the best photo spot by the Torre del Oro is just to the north of the tower (on the right hand side if you‚Äôre looking at it facing the river), on the Paseo Mayor Marques del Contadero. Here, you get a bit of the river, the tower, and the palm trees all in the shot.
sources.shortName: 14 Gorgeous, Most Instagrammable Places in Seville, Spain

sources.snippet: La Torre del Oro, or the Tower of Gold, is another Instagrammable spot in Seville. This iconic tower, situated on the banks of the Guadalquivir River, offers a unique photo opportunity. With its distinctive cylindrical shape, golden hue, and picturesque waterfront location, it provides a captivating subject for photography.
sources.shortName: 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Seville (2024)

sources.snippet: In our opinion, the best place to photograph the ‚ÄúGolden Tower‚Äù is from Puente San Telmo (the bridge). It is a beautiful angle compared to right next to the tower, as you can capture the beauty of the Guadalquivir River as well. We recommend photographing this tower around sunset when the sun is shining right on the tower.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Most Instagrammable places in Seville 2019 | by Lucas Garcia

sources.snippet: The Torre del Oro is a little Tower on the riverside of Guadalquivir River. When visiting Sevilla you should take a walk along the river and maybe relax from the city‚Äôs heat in the shadow on the riverside. Here you can see Puenta de Triana and Torre del Oro which has beautiful light in the evening and afternoon.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographers guide to Sevilla

sources.snippet: Built in 1220, this iconic tower was originally part of the city's defensive walls. The 36-meter-tall monument stands on the left bank of the Guadalquivir River and was designed as a watchtower to protect against invasions. Golden-hued tiles once covered the tower, which explains its name: "Tower of Gold.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

sources.snippet: One of the great symbols of Seville, la torre del Oro won¬¥t leave you indifferent. Due to its ideal location near by the Guadalquivir river, torre del Oro will give you stunning photos for your Instagram profile day and night. With 57.9K publications, torre del Oro is a must monument to Instagram.
sources.shortName: THE 5 MOST INSTAGRAMMABLE PLACES IN SEVILLE ‚Äì Photo Tour Seville ‚Äì Things to do, activities and what to see in Seville

sources.snippet: Torre del Oro or the Tower of Gold is a 13th-century defensive watchtower built in order to control the access to Seville from the Guadalquivir river. It got its name because the tower reflected a golden shine in the river. And it does look pretty golden in the morning sun too, haha!
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: In the 13th century there was a tower on either side of the river, but the one on the Triana riverbank didnt survive. Built in 1221 this medieval structure has had many uses of the years. These towers were for collecting taxes and controlling ships coming into the city.
sources.shortName: Photogenic Seville & its most instagrammable spots

sources.snippet: Also known as the ‚ÄúGolden Tower‚Äù, the Torre del Oro dates from the 13th century. It once formed part of the city walls. The watch tower protected the city from invaders and oversaw the ships that sailed on the Guadalquivir River.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: This tower is a pretty spot to stop for a little bit to gather your thoughts and grab a picture. It was built in the 13th century as a watchtower but was also used as a jail at various times. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Seville

sources.snippet: During your walking tour in Seville, step by Torre de Oro*, a watchtower located on the riverbank and let your imagination start as it is one of the best photos of Spain*.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable Seville | The Best Photography Guide Of Andalusia

places.name: Torre del Oro

reviews.text:
Visiting the Torre del Oro was a fantastic experience and a highlight of my trip to Seville. This historic tower, standing proudly along the Guadalquivir River, offers not only a glimpse into Seville's maritime past but also some of the best panoramic views of the city.
The architecture of the tower is striking, with its Moorish design and golden hue that gives it its name. The small naval museum inside was an interesting stop, showcasing artifacts, maps, and models that illustrate Seville's rich connection to naval exploration. While the museum is relatively modest, it provides great insight into the tower's historical significance.
Climbing to the top was the best part. The view of the river, the Cathedral, and the city's rooftops was absolutely stunning-perfect for photos! It's especially breathtaking at sunset.

The entrance fee was quite reasonable, and the visit didn't take too long, making it an easy stop to fit into a busy itinerary. If you're in Seville and love history, architecture, or simply great views, I highly recommend adding the Torre del Oro to your must-visit list ü§©ü§©

Definitely Worth visiting the spectacular naval museum Torre del Oro. The entrance was free of charge. On my first visit, there was a crowded tourist group and a long queue, so I decided to come back later. One hour later the tower was suitable. On the first floor, a souvenir store is available, upper floors are museum full of naval relics and info. The top of the tower is a kind of terrace and has a nice view of the surroundings.

Free entry, they will ask you for any donation at the entry, even if it's ¬£1 they will be happy so you choose the price of your ticket!

Very interesting and has lovely ship models with a lot of history facts to learn.

At the top you can take a picture of a lovely view of the city!

places.address: The Golden Tower, P.¬∫ de Crist√≥bal Col√≥n, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41001 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: The Archivo de Indias is a Renaissance building that has been designated as a World Heritage site. It houses an extensive collection of documents related to the Spanish Empire. The city of Seville, where the archive is located, is known for its rich history and architectural wonders such as the Giralda, the Cathedral, Reales Alcazares, Torre del Oro, and many more.

sources.snippet: Across from the Alc√°zar is the 16th-century Casa Lonja de Mercaderes (merchants' exchange building), which houses the UNESCO-listed Archivo General de Indias, an archive of documents from Spain's colonial years in the New World. Two of the archives' most significant treasures are Christopher Columbus's personal journal and the papal bull issued by Pope Alexander VI, which divided the New World between Spain and Portugal. The General Archive of the Indies was created by the Spanish government during the reign of Carlos III, for the purpose of the administration of overseas territories.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Seville | PlanetWare

sources.snippet: If you are looking for a unique place to explore right in the heart of Seville Old Town then Archivo de Indias is the place to go. It is a national archive housing documents about the colonization times and the New World era. The best part ‚Äì it is free to visit!
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: Located right in the heart of the city is the Archivo de Indias. Here, you can explore thousands of documents that delve into Spain‚Äôs colonial past. Although the view from the outside is nice ‚Äì it‚Äôs the inside that we particularly like here.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: An archive that has more than 10 kilometers of bookshelves, all filled with documents from the colonial history of South America (Las Indias).

places.name: Archivo de Indias

reviews.text:
Here are the reasons why you should visit this museum/archive:
1. It's for free.
2. It's actually quite interesting, and you get to learn about the Spanish expeditions in the 16th and 17th centuries.
3. The AC is really nice. Get out of the scorching sun and enjoy culture in fresh, dark rooms.

Located just right next to the Catedral de Sevilla, Archivo de Indias will be a nice short visit to see another part of history in this city. The rooms where they put all the archives are beautiful. We spent around 30 minutes here, with a nice history telling to our kids.

Free museum at the building where they stored all the archives from Spanish colonial times. There are portraits of the directors of the archive, as well as information on the trips of discovery and colonialism. It is a beautiful building right next to the Cathedral of Sevilla and it is worth a short visit, it should not take more than half an hour to visit all of it.

places.address: Av. de la Constituci√≥n, s/n, Casco Antiguo, 41004 Sevilla, Spain

places.generalDescription: Arco de la Macarena is a striking 12th-century gate located just north of the city center in the Macarena neighborhood of Seville. It is part of the largest remaining sections of the original Moorish city wall, built by the Almohad dynasty. The area around Arco de la Macarena has evolved into a modern and commercially important part of town, housing significant landmarks such as the Andalusian parliament and Seville's oldest market, Mercado de la Feria.

sources.snippet: In case you are hanging around the North part of Seville‚Äôs Old Town then you can consider visiting this cool spot ‚Äì Arco de la Macarena arch next to the Bas√≠lica de la Macarena church. Both are unique because both of the buildings are painted in yellow color and stand out in the surrounding area. Arco de la Macarena arch dates back to the 12th century when it served as the city gate to Seville and was part of the ancient city walls.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: This pretty yellow-coloured gateway dates back to the 16th century. It‚Äôs one of the few gates into Seville that still survives ‚Äì it‚Äôs still attached to one of the longest stretches of the ancient city walls. It is located in a neighbourhood in the north of the old city.

reviews.text: As a monuments is not amazing but your van see the old city wall from there. Or is however a good spot for a quick stop with the car when your need to pick up or drop off people
Part of the visitor attractions of Seville but not so well known. Great arch, medieval walls and church

Worth a visit to see the 12th century walls that stretch out on one side with the moat and primarywall. The arch in itself isn't so much of a sight but therex are much smaller passages through the wall which are more visually impactive and you can get right up close to see the stonework. The church is obviously just on the left of the wall too

places.generalDescription: Plaza de Am√©rica is a historic square in Seville, built for the 1929 Ibero-American Exhibition. It features ornate pavilions surrounding a pond and gardens. The square is located within Maria Luisa Park, which also houses three architectural gems from the Expo: the Mudejar Pavilion (now the Museum of Popular Arts and Customs), the Renaissance Palace (now the Archaeological Museum), and the Royal Pavilion.

sources.snippet: Another unique corner connected to Mar√≠a Luisa Park is Plaza de Am√©rica. As you will notice with many places around Seville, a lot of places here were built and created for the Ibero-American Exhibition in 1929 to make the city more beautiful and full of picturesque places. Plaza de Am√©rica features picturesque ponds, ornate gardens, and pavillions around it that make a beautiful reflection in the water if you look at it from the right angle.
sources.shortName: 25 most famous Instagram spots in Seville, Spain (+map!)

sources.snippet: Located in the southern end of Parque de Mar√≠a Luisa is one of our favourite plazas because it‚Äôs where you‚Äôll find three of Seville‚Äôs most gorgeous buildings. The Museum of Popular Arts, the Archaeological Museum, and the Royal Pavilion, each boasting diverse styles from Neomud√©jar to Renaissance. The buildings each have intricate patterns and colourful facades with floral courtyards, and fountains.
sources.shortName: 34 Best Seville Instagram Spots (+ Map)

sources.snippet: Plaza de America is the little brother of Plaza de Espa√±a (nr3). The buildings were built by An√≠bal Gonz√°lez for the future Ibero-American exhibition in 1929. Just like the Plaza de Espa√±a.

places.name: Plaza de Am√©rica

reviews.text: Really cute part of the Parque de Maria Luis. Perfect spot to chill, enjoy the sun, beautiful nature and the architecture.

Plaza de Am√©rica in Seville is a stunning and vibrant square located within the beautiful Mar√≠a Luisa Park. Surrounded by impressive buildings such as the Archaeological Museum and the Museum of Popular Arts and Traditions, the plaza showcases a mix of architectural styles, including Renaissance and Moorish influences. The large central fountain adds to its charm, creating a peaceful atmosphere. The square is a perfect place to wander, take photos, and enjoy the surrounding greenery and historical monuments.

Just next to Maria Luisa Parque it's beautiful to see I didn't visit the museum but the outside is pretty ! You can seat there and enjoy your time but watch out the sun ! There isn't a shadow place unless you go back inside the park
